questions.text: Urine sample of a patient has been collected for analysis. How soon should it be analyzed?
questions.solution:
Urine samples should be analyzed within 2-4 hours after collection to avoid cell lysis and precipitation of solutes. If urine analysis is not possible in the given time, then the sample can be stored at 4-8 oC for a maximum of 12 hours.

Urine samples can be collected using the following techniques:

  • Midstream sample during spontaneous voiding
  • Fresh specimen from an indwelling catheter
  • Suprapubic needle aspiration of the bladder, especially in infants

questions.text: All of the following determine the color of urine except:
questions.solution:
The solubility of solutes is not a determining factor of the color of urine. Determinants of the color of urine are:

  • Chemical content 
  • Concentration 
  • pH (Normal pH is 4.5-8)

The normal color of urine is pale straw due to the presence of urochrome.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause green-colored urine in a patient?
questions.solution:
Green urine can be caused by triamterene, a potassium-sparing diuretic.

Related Pearl: Color of urine in different conditions

Normal color of urine is pale straw due to presence of urochrome.

questions.text: What value of urine specific gravity is called isosthenuria?
questions.solution:
Isosthenuria is defined as a urine specific gravity of 1.010, which is similar to that of plasma. The normal specific gravity of urine is around 1.020 to 1.030. 

Specific gravity and osmolality are measures of the concentration or relative density of urine.

  • Specific gravity: The weight of a solution relative to that of equal amounts of water. It is measured by refractometry or using reagent strips.
  • Osmolality: The gold standard for relative density. It is defined as the number of osmoles of solute per kilogram of solvent. It is measured directly with an osmometer.

Isosthenuria means that the kidney is neither concentrating nor diluting the urine. This is seen in chronic renal failure (CRF) and acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

Abnormality Causes
Isosthenuria

CRF, ATN
Hyposthenuria (low specific gravity) Diabetes insipidus

Hypersthenuria (high specific gravity)

SIADH, Severe dehydration

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for the following appearance of his urine. A urine dipstick test is performed and the result is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows reddish discoloration of the urine sample. A negative urine dipstick indicates absence of RBCs and is suggestive of porphyria.

A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme that is present in red blood cells, haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or porphyrias.

questions.text:
Which of the following patients are considered to have significant hematuria based on their urine analysis findings?
  1. A 30-year-old patient with RBC >3 / HPF on 2 occasions
  2. A 23-year-old woman with RBC >100 / HPF on 1 occasion
  3. A 56-year-old man with RBC >10 / HPF on 1 occasion
  4. An 18-year-old student with RBC >3 / HPF on 3 occasions
  5. A 40-year-old patient with gross hematuria
questions.solution:
Hematuria is defined as the presence of 2-5 RBCs / high-powered field (HPF). It is considered significant or persistent in the presence of one of the following:

  • RBCs > 3 / HPF on 3 or more occasions
  • RBCs > 100 / HPF on 1 occasion
  • Gross hematuria

questions.text: A patient with hematuria, generalized edema, and abdominal distension is suspected to have a glomerular pathology. Which of the following is likely to be seen in the urine?
questions.solution:
Acanthocytes are a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs that are seen in glomerular disease.

The 40-5-1 rule can be used to identify glomerular diseases based on urinalysis:

  • Dysmorphic RBCs - 40% (can range from 10-80%)
  • Acanthocytes - 5% (can range from 2-5%)
  • Even a single RBC cast

Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below:

Glomerular Non-glomerular

Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size)

Isomorphic RBCs seen (normal shape and size)

RBC casts may be present

RBC casts always absent

MCV  is reduced (<72 fl)

MCV is normal

Protein excretion > 1g /day

Protein excretion < 1g /day

The cause is usually medical

The cause is usually surgical

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of malaise.  He was diagnosed with mild sensorineural hearing loss nearly 10 years ago. He also has a history of recurrent hematuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Alport syndrome. The clinical features include:

  • Recurrent hematuria and nephritic syndrome
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Anterior lenticonus

 Other causes of recurrent hematuria include:

  • Alport syndrome
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Papillary necrosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is true about proteinuria?

choices.text: Proteinuria is always due to glomerular pathology
Albuminuria upto 150 mg/day is considered normal
Proteins are reabsorbed in the DCT

questions.solution:
Nephrotic-range or heavy proteinuria refers to excretion of > 3.5 g/day or > 1000 mg/m2/day in children.

Type of Proteinuria

  Total proteinuria (mg/day)

Albuminuria (mg/day)

Normal-range

 

<150  

Mainly Tamm-Horsfall protein (70-75 mg/day) 

< 30
Moderately increased 150-500  30-300 
Severely increased > 500  > 300  
Orthostatic proteinuria 150-500   —

Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria:

  • The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged and large proteins.
  • Reabsorption of small proteins in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT).

The various types of proteinuria are:

  1. Glomerular - increased filtration of proteins due to disruption of basement membrane
  2. Tubular - damage to tubules prevents protein reabsorption in the PCT
  3. Overflow - excess production of low molecular weight proteins such as light chains
  4. Postrenal - infections or stones can lead to secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract

questions.text: All of the following findings in a patient are suggestive of non-glomerular proteinuria except:

choices.text: Type of protein excreted is β2-microglobulin

questions.solution:
Non-glomerular proteinuria is characterized by the presence of N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG).

This form of proteinuria occurs as a result of tubular injury. N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG) is a lysosomal enzyme present in the proximal tubular cells and is released into the urine following any injury to the tubules.

Low-molecular-weight proteins such as β2-microglobulin are normally reabsorbed in the PCT. When there is tubular injury, the proportion of these proteins in urine increases. This lowers the albumin: β2-microglobulin ratio in urine.

In glomerular proteinuria, there is increased filtration of macromolecules like albumin across the glomerular capillary wall. NAG is absent as there is no tubular injury.

  Glomerular proteinuria Non-glomerular proteinuria

Type of protein excreted

 High molecular weight (Albumin) Low molecular weight (β2-microglobulin)

24 hr protein excretion

 > 1-2 g/day < 1 g/day 

RBC casts

 Present Absent

Albumin: β2 microglobulin ratio (Normal 100:1)

 1000:1 10:1

N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG)

 Absent Present

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of urine is shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent feature in patients with cystinuria.

Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends upon a variety of factors including:

  • The degree of concentration of constituent molecules
  • The urine pH
  • The presence of inhibitors of crystallization

Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about casts in urine?

choices.text: Width of cast depends on the size of tubule in which it is formed
Casts in urine are specific to kidneys
Site of formation is  proximal convoluted tubule
Casts are made up of uromodulin

questions.solution:
The sites of formation of casts are the collecting ducts and DCTs (distal convoluted tubules).

Casts are cylindrical structures formed by the aggregation of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein or uromodulin. This protein is secreted in the thick ascending loop of Henle. They assume the shape and size of the lumen in which they are formed. Several factors favour cast formation, such as urine stasis, low pH and high concentration. Casts are the only elements in urine sediments that are specifically of renal origin. 

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A patient with cryptococcal meningitis was started on amphotericin B. Two days later, he is found to have decreased urine output. Urinalysis reveals granular casts. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Muddy-brown granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, a type of intrinsic renal failure. ATN can occur secondary to nephrotoxicity or hypovolemia.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: Which of the following casts are associated with a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Broad casts are associated with a poor prognosis.

They refer to wider waxy casts that are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease. It implies dilation of the tubules.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance
